attributes.comment:
By increasing fee schedules for green card and U.S. Citizenship applications
certainly supports the funding for an up-to-date technology resolution for a more
sufficient, streamline processing time. There is tremendous amount of
immigrations coming to America every year. This does not only reflect the fact of
population increase but it also means increasing of work forces, income
generation, and American culture value for its diversity.

U.S citizens and Non-U.S. citizens all work hard and pay their taxes. Everyone
benefits from their own contributions. It is definitely the immigrants are responsible
for their own fees. However, a Non-permanent immigrant is usually facing more
challenge in finding works due to his/her alien status than it is to a Permanent
resident or a U.S. Citizen. Yet he or she still have to pay taxes like everyone else
and is not entitle to the right to vote, Medicare or other benefits available.

It is true for those who files I-485 form also files I-765 form concurrently. How
about individuals who already got approved for I-485 and filing N-400 (Application
for Naturalization)? Permanent Residents who received green card and file for N-
400 do not need to pay extra fee obligation that does not apply to them, they have
the right to work and do not need employment authorization permit.

U.S. Citizens do not pay for this immigration process, the immigrants pay for
themselves. Why increase the fees by assuming everyone files for certain
applications? Why not let them pay accordingly to their individual needs or
status?

I OBJECT TO THE PROPOSED RULE "Adjustment of the Immigration and
Naturalization Benefit Application and Petition Fee Schedule? FROM $325 FOR I-
485 AND $330 FOR N-400 TO $905.

Instead of $905 fee for all the application, a fee adjustment of $509 (application
$325 plus employment authorization $180) for I-485 form should be proposed. N-
400 fee of $330 should remain same as before. PLUS ANY OTHER FEES MAY
REQUIRED.

Have you ever consider the financial difficulty of a typical working family of 5
households has to face with the new proposed fee schedule? $905 x 5 = $4,525
plus biometric fee or other fees. This is not a small amount of money anyone can
afford.

If the proposed fee schedule should passed, there should be a waiver program for
qualified candidates or installment plans for those who do not meet the criteria of
low income and unable to pay a lump sum amount.

KEEP IN MIND IF YOU ARE A PERMANENT RESIDENT, YOU WORK HARD TO
SUPPORT YOUR FAMILY AND PAY TAXES. YET DUE TO THE NEW RULE
YOU MIGHT NOT BE ABLE TO AFFORD TO BECOME A U.S. CITIZEN AND
YOUR VOICE WOULD NOT BE HEARD BECAUSE YOU DO NOT HAVE THE
RIGHT TO VOTE.
"ALL MEN ARE CREATED EQUAL"
